title: Question 24

children: A 62-year-old man is evaluated in the emergency department for a rash that developed over his entire body during the past week. He was discharged from the hospital 15 days ago for a COPD exacerbation. He received prednisone for 5 days and levofloxacin for 7 days. Medical history is significant for chronic plaque psoriasis that he does not treat. Medications are tiotropium and salmeterol-fluticasone.

On physical examination, the patient appears ill and is bundled in blankets and shivering. Temperature is 37 °C (98.6 °F); other vital signs are normal. The rash covers 90% of body surface area. Representative skin and nail findings are
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Erythroderma describes the condition of erythema covering greater than 80% body surface area.
Up to 40% of cases of erythroderma are idiopathic; exacerbation of a preexisting rash (e.g., psoriasis, atopic dermatitis) and medication reaction are other common etiologies.
The most likely diagnosis is erythroderma (

), specifically erythrodermic psoriasis. Erythroderma is a descriptive term for erythema covering greater than 80% body surface area. Up to 40% of cases are idiopathic; exacerbation of a preexisting rash (e.g., psoriasis, atopic dermatitis) and medication reaction are other common etiologies. Psoriasis can flare violently to erythrodermic psoriasis after exposure to systemic glucocorticoids; for this reason, systemic corticosteroids are very rarely used for treatment of psoriasis. However, patients receiving glucocorticoids for other conditions may develop an erythrodermic flare. Erythrodermic psoriasis can be fatal, with mortality resulting from fluid loss, high-output heart failure, infection, hypothermia, or hypocalcemia (because calcium is consumed during the rapid turnover of keratinocytes).

Nail changes are not typical of DIHS. The time course and appearance of nearly total body erythema in this patient make DIHS an unlikely diagnosis.
